captions.text:
Sea level seems like a pretty easy concept,
right? You just measure the average level

of the oceans and that's that. But what about
parts of the earth where there aren't oceans?

For example, when we say that Mt. Everest
is 8850m above sea level, how do we know what

sea level would be beneath Mt. Everest, since
there's no sea for hundreds of kilometers?

If the earth were flat then things would be
easy - we'd just draw a straight line through

the average height of the oceans and be done
with it. But the earth isn't flat.

If the earth were spherical, it would be easy,
too, because we could just measure the average

distance from the center of the earth to the
surface of the ocean. But the earth isn't

spherical - it's spinning, so bits closer
to the equator are "thrown out" by centrifugal

effects, and the poles get squashed in a bit.
In fact, the earth is so non-spherical that

it's 42km farther across at the equator than
from pole to pole. That means if you thought

earth were a sphere and defined sea level
by standing on the sea ice at the north pole,

then the surface of the ocean at the equator
would be 21km above sea level.

This bulging is also why the Chimborazo volcano
in Ecuador, and not Mount Everest, is the

peak that's actually farthest from the center
of the earth.

So how do we know what sea level is? Well,
water is held on earth by gravity, so we could

model the earth as a flattened & stretched
spinning sphere and then calculate what height

the oceans would settle to when pulled by
gravity onto the surface of that ellipsoid.

Except the interior of the earth doesn't have
the same density everywhere, which means gravity

is slightly stronger or weaker at different
points around the globe, and the oceans tend

"puddle" more nearer to the dense spots. These
aren't small changes, either - the level of

the sea can vary by up to 100m from a uniform
ellipsoid depending on the density of the

earth beneath it. And on top of that, literally,
there are those pesky things called continents

moving around on the earth's surface. These
dense lumps of rock bump out from the ellipsoid

and their mass gravitationally attracts oceans,
while valleys in the ocean floor have less
mass and the oceans flow away, shallower.

And this is the real conundrum, because the
very presence of a mountain (& continent on

which it sits) changes the level of the sea:
the gravitational attraction of land pulls

more water nearby, raising the sea around
it. So, to determine the height of a mountain

above sea level, should we use the height
the sea would be if the mountain weren't there

at all? Or the height the sea would be if
the mountain weren't there but its gravity
were?

The people who worry about such things, called
geodetic scientists or geodesists, decided

that we should indeed define sea level using
the strength of gravity, so they went about

creating an incredibly detailed model of the
earth's gravitational field, called, creatively,

the Earth Gravitational Model. It's incorporated
into modern GPS receivers so they won't tell

you you're 100m below sea level when you're
in fact sitting on the beach in Sri Lanka

which has weak gravity, and has allowed geodesists
themselves to correctly predict the average

level of the ocean to within a meter everywhere
on earth. Which is why we also use it to define

what sea level would be underneath mountains...
if they weren't there... but their gravity
was.

comments.author: Adi Nugroho

comments.text:
+Adi Nugroho  Note that a sphere is a "degenerate ellipsoid", so... the 
Earth would be an ellipsoid whether or not it was a perfect sphere.

Anyway... "round" has the exact definition of "Having every portion of the 
surface or of the circumference *equally* distant from the center".  Thus, 
even though the Earth *looks* round, and is -- in fact -- rounder than 
anything we can make, it's still not round.

comments.author: Celso Arai Jr.

comments.text:
For the definition of altitude, yes. It's an arbitrary definition, and you 
have to draw the line somewhere.

The tidal force can be modeled as a vector differential field in space and 
applied to the geoid, but to compute those values you now have to take into 
account time and the position of the moon when you want to make sense of an 
altitude value. Apart from the conceptual baggage, the actual differences 
are negligible, the magnitude of the inaccuracy in WG84 is much bigger.

Furthermore, even with the factors for how much the moon would pull in what 
direction, the way tides work is actually different because the water can 
only flow around land and at a certain rate, it wobbles and sloshes and 
what not, it's just not easily predictable. Instead we talk about these 
data rich, observable changes in sea level with respect to our definition 
of altitude, and not the other way around, so that things stay simpler at 
the levels of abstraction that we find convenient for experiencing the 
universe.

That doesn't mean people are ignoring the tides, they just have to if they 
want to talk about them in terms of some fixed point, and the concept of 
altitude provides fixed points to relate to, and that they don't want to 
talk about the tides and the moon phase every time they describe an 
elevation on a point of land.

comments.author: Korsos

comments.text:
I'd say that the zeros and ones are not a random sequence. I did an 
analysis of the microstates (before spending 10 minutes doing this I did 
the obvious and checked if it translated into anything interesting from 
ascii to no avail) for combinations of one, two three, and four number 
fragments. In a random generation, there would be roughly equal occurrences 
for each microstate, give or take because of the small sample size, but in 
the above sequence there was no semblance of uniformity between 
microstates, especially when analyzing the larger sequence fragments the 
apparent randomness faded away as three or four of the 16 microstates (2^4) 
were used most of the time. It's still amazing, though, because even if the 
sequence were made by "randomly" pressing one and zero on a keyboard, it's 
not a truly random sequence, and I think that says something about the 
human mind and it's tendencies towards patterns, to the point that it 
inadvertently can create them, because all that science really is (at a 
very basic level) is the search for patterns in the world around us. I 
could rant on for a while about the fallibility of those tendencies, like 
how people always seem to forget that correlation isn't causation because 
patterns always feel so right to us, but let's just marvel at the 
complexity of our own minds instead.﻿

comments.author: TheAthens619

comments.text:
The 1's and 0's are more flip-floppy than they should be if random.  The 
value stays the same (00 or 11) 38 times, and flips (01 or 10) 61 times.  A 
random string of 1's and 0's would only be this flip-floppy about 2% of the 
time (including more extreme results of flip-floppiness or streakiness). 
 We humans tend to prefer flip-flops when looking for randomness because we 
see long strings of the same value as non-random.  We could do other 
analyses of features like the average streak length, and I think we would 
reach similar conclusions.﻿

comments.author: coolcoonscaptures “jakendaker” bendy

comments.text:
+coolcoonscaptures bendy Centripetal means center-seeking, and it's what 
forces objects travelling in a circle to stay in a circle. Centrifugal 
means center-fleeing, and it's when an object being spun around appears to 
be flung outward. They're two very different concepts (albeit existing for 
the same reason), and even though they're not forces per-se, both do exist.

often on a relatively limited scale up to a few dozen km.
